questions.text: A 55-year-old woman has difficulty seeing in bright light and is diagnosed with a cataract. Which cataract type is not typically associated with this symptom?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cuneiform cataract

 

Cuneiform (cortical) cataract begins as wedge-shaped opacities in the lens cortex, typically starting peripherally and moving inward. Patients mainly complain of poor vision in dim light because the dilated pupil allows light to pass through the opaque peripheral lens. It is not associated with difficulty seeing in bright light. Instead, patients often report night glare and haloes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nuclear cataract: Affects the central nucleus of the lens. Causes difficulty in bright light due to increased light scatter and glare. Patients may notice a temporary improvement in near vision (“second sight”), but distant vision worsens in sunlight.

 

Option C. Posterior subcapsular cataract: Opacity lies just in front of the posterior capsule. Vision becomes worse in bright light and while reading, because pupil constriction directs light through the cloudy posterior area. Common in diabetics and those on steroids.

 

Option D. Steroid-induced cataract: Typically a posterior subcapsular variety. Produces photophobia and glare in bright light, similar to idiopathic posterior subcapsular cataract.

questions.text: The following image is an indication of toxicity due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Digoxin

 

The image shown is “The Night Café” by Vincent van Gogh, which is classically used to depict xanthopsia (yellow vision) — a characteristic visual disturbance caused by digoxin toxicity.

 

Digoxin toxicity affects color perception due to its action on the retina and visual cortex, leading to:

 

  • Yellow or green vision (xanthopsia)
  • Blurred vision or halos around lights
  • Scotomas or flickering lights

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amiodarone: Can cause corneal microdeposits, optic neuropathy, or bluish skin discoloration (“blue man syndrome”), but not yellow vision.

 

Option C. Chloroquine: Produces bull’s-eye maculopathy and irreversible retinopathy with long-term use. Symptoms include central scotoma and blurred vision, not xanthopsia.

 

Option D. Ethambutol: Causes optic neuritis, leading to red-green color blindness and decreased visual acuity, but no yellow discoloration.

questions.text: A patient recently underwent LASIK surgery for her myopia. She is now complaining of headaches and eye pain. Identify the test being performed on her:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tonometry

 

The image shows a tonometry test, which is performed to measure intraocular pressure (IOP) — an important assessment, especially after LASIK surgery, where elevated IOP can occur due to steroid-induced glaucoma or post-surgical changes.

 

Tonometry uses a slit-lamp-mounted applanation device (usually Goldmann applanation tonometer) that gently flattens a small part of the cornea to determine the pressure inside the eye.

 

The patient’s symptoms of headache and eye pain after LASIK surgery raise suspicion for raised intraocular pressure, making tonometry the appropriate test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pachymetry: Measures corneal thickness using ultrasound or optical methods. It is important before LASIK to ensure adequate corneal thickness but not used for postoperative headache or pain.

 

 

 

Option C. Auto-refractometry: Determines the refractive error (myopia, hypermetropia, astigmatism) automatically. Used for prescribing lenses, not for IOP measurement.

 

 

Option D. Slit-lamp examination: Used to examine anterior segment structures (cornea, iris, lens, anterior chamber). It provides visualization but does not measure pressure.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents with progressive proptosis of his right eye. The proptosis increases on bending forward and is compressible. No thrill or bruit was present. MRI is shown below. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Orbital venolymphatic

 

The MRI image shows a right-sided orbital lesion causing proptosis that is compressible and increases on bending forward (dependent position) — classic of orbital varix/ venolymphatic malformation due to fluid-fluid levels, a type of low-flow venous malformation.

 

Orbital varices are thin-walled, distensible venous channels within the orbit that communicate with the normal venous system.

 

  • Proptosis increases when venous pressure rises (e.g., on Valsalva maneuver, bending forward, or coughing) because the varix becomes engorged.
  • Proptosis decreases or disappears at rest or when the patient is supine.
  • No thrill or bruit distinguishes it from an arteriovenous fistula.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital A-V fistula: Characterized by pulsatile proptosis, thrill and bruit, and often conjunctival congestion with corkscrew vessels due to high-flow arterial shunt→ Not seen here.

 

Option C. Neurofibromatosis: Causes plexiform neurofibromas leading to S-shaped ptosis or non-compressible proptosis→ No compressibility or change with posture.

 

Option D. Orbital encephalocele: Results from herniation of intracranial contents into the orbit through a bony defect.
Proptosis is non-compressible and non-pulsatile; MRI shows continuity with intracranial structures.

questions.text: Which of the systemic diseases is associated with the following appearance?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sarcoidosis

 

Image shows BAND SHAPED KERATOPATHY (VOGT’s LIMBAL GIRDLE). It is Corneal degeneration deposition of calcium hydroxyapatite
in sub-epithelium, Bowman's layer and the anterior stroma. It is associated with JIA. Band-shaped keratopathy (BSK) is a corneal degenerative condition characterized by calcium deposition in the superficial layers of the cornea — specifically in Bowman’s layer and the superficial stroma, typically in the interpalpebral zone.

 

It appears as a grayish-white, horizontal band across the central cornea with clear intervals near the limbus and “Swiss cheese” holes (clear areas around corneal nerves).

 

Systemic Association: Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA)

 

  • Chronic anterior uveitis in JIA leads to persistent intraocular inflammation, which in turn causes degenerative calcium deposition in the cornea → band-shaped keratopathy.
  • This is especially seen in long-standing, untreated JIA-associated uveitis, often in young girls.
  • The keratopathy contributes to decreased vision and photophobia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sarcoidosis: Incorrect.

 

  • Sarcoidosis causes granulomatous uveitis, not band-shaped keratopathy directly.
  • May cause mutton-fat keratic precipitates, but no band-shaped calcium deposition.

 

Option B. Vitamin A deficiency: Incorrect. Causes xerophthalmia, Bitot’s spots, keratomalacia, and corneal ulceration, not calcium deposition in a band-like pattern.

 

Option C. Tuberculosis: Incorrect. TB may cause granulomatous uveitis or phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis, but not band-shaped keratopathy.

questions.text: Name the location of the nucleus supplying the muscle marked with the question mark in the image given below:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Superior colliculus

 

The highlighted muscle is the medial rectus, which is supplied by the oculomotor nerve. The nucleus of the oculomotor nerve is situated at the level of the superior colliculus. The oculomotor nerve arises from a nuclear complex that includes the oculomotor nucleus and Edinger-Westphal preganglionic nucleus. The oculomotor nucleus is comprised of several groups of large motor neurons that innervate the ipsilateral inferior rectus, inferior oblique, and medial rectus in dorsoventral order. Additionally, a column of cells located medially innervates the contralateral superior rectus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior olivary: This is part of the auditory pathway and has no involvement in eye muscle control.

 

Option B. Inferior colliculus: Also part of the auditory pathway, located in the midbrain but not involved in motor control of eye movements.

 

Option D. Fascial colliculus: This term is likely a typographical error for "facial colliculus," which refers to a structure in the brainstem associated with the facial nerve, not the oculomotor nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The nucleus of the oculomotor nerve, responsible for innervating the medial rectus muscle among others, is located at the level of the superior colliculus in the midbrain. This is crucial for understanding the neural control of eye movements, particularly in how various components of the eye are coordinated for proper visual alignment and focus.

questions.text: The most common cause of proptosis in middle-aged individuals is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thyroid eye disease

 

Thyroid eye disease (TED) — also called Graves’ ophthalmopathy or thyroid-associated orbitopathy — is the most common cause of proptosis in middle-aged adults.

 

It is an autoimmune inflammatory disorder in which activated T-lymphocytes target orbital fibroblasts and pre-adipocytes, leading to:

 

  • Enlargement of extraocular muscles (classically sparing tendinous insertions)
  • Increased orbital fat and connective tissue
  • Resultant axial proptosis (bilateral or unilateral)

 

Typical features:

 

  • Lid retraction (“stare” appearance)
  • Periorbital edema, conjunctival chemosis
  • Diplopia (due to extraocular muscle restriction)
  • Exposure keratopathy
  • Optic neuropathy (in severe cases)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cavernous hemangioma:

 

  • Most common benign orbital tumor in adults, but causes slowly progressive unilateral proptosis rather than bilateral or fluctuating proptosis.
  • Typically seen in women, located within the intraconal space, and not inflammatory in nature.
  • Hence, it is a cause of proptosis but not the most common overall.

 

Option B. Orbital varix:

 

  • A venous malformation leading to intermittent, positional proptosis (worsens on bending forward or straining).
  • Seen in younger adults, less common than thyroid orbitopathy.

 

Option D. Retinoblastoma:

 

  • Malignant retinal tumor occurring in children, not middle-aged individuals.
  • Proptosis in retinoblastoma is secondary to orbital extension of the tumor, not primary orbital pathology.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of complicated cataracts?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Krukenberg spindle

 

Krukenberg spindle is not a feature of complicated cataract.
It refers to a vertical, spindle-shaped deposit of pigment on the posterior surface of the cornea (endothelium), typically seen in pigment dispersion syndrome or pigmentary glaucoma, not in cataracts.

 

The pigment originates from the posterior surface of the iris and gets deposited on the corneal endothelium due to aqueous convection currents.

 

Thus, while it’s an ophthalmic finding, it is unrelated to complicated cataract formation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Polychromatic lustre: Seen in complicated cataracts, where the lens shows multicolored reflexes when illuminated due to changes in refractive index of degenerating lens fibers.
This iridescent appearance is a hallmark of chronic inflammatory cataract.

 

 

Option C. Occurs after uveitis: Complicated cataract develops secondary to chronic intraocular inflammation, especially anterior uveitis, iridocyclitis, or retinitis.
Inflammation alters lens metabolism leading to opacification — hence, this is a classic cause.

 

Option D. Breadcrumb appearance: Refers to irregular, grayish-white opacities in the posterior subcapsular region of the lens — characteristic of complicated cataract due to inflammatory deposits resembling “bread crumbs.”

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of acute chest pain. Her blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg and pulse is 42/min. An ECG reveals ST-segment elevation in the inferior leads. The appropriate therapy is initiated, including a medication to treat her bradycardia. After initial treatment, her blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg and pulse is 76/min. However, she now complains of severe right-sided eye pain. Which of the following is the most likely cause for this patient's eye pain?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glaucoma

 

Clinical summary:

 

  • Elderly woman with inferior wall myocardial infarction (ST elevation in inferior leads)
  • Bradycardia (pulse 42/min) initially → treated → HR improved
  • Now develops acute severe right-sided eye pain

 

This sequence points toward acute angle-closure glaucoma caused by atropine, a drug commonly used to treat bradycardia in inferior MI.

 

Mechanism:

 

  • Inferior wall MI often involves the right coronary artery, which supplies the SA and AV nodes, leading to sinus bradycardia or AV block.
  • Treatment: Atropine, a muscarinic (M2) receptor antagonist, increases heart rate by blocking vagal tone.

 

However, atropine also blocks M3 receptors in the eye, causing:

 

  • Mydriasis (pupil dilation) → narrows the iridocorneal angle → obstructs aqueous humor outflow → sudden rise in intraocular pressure.
    → Result: Acute angle-closure glaucoma

 

Symptoms:

 

  • Sudden severe eye pain
  • Blurred vision, haloes around lights
  • Mid-dilated, non-reactive pupil
  • Corneal haze and redness
  • Often accompanied by nausea and vomiting

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iridocyclitis (anterior uveitis):

 

  • Causes dull ocular pain and photophobia, not sudden severe pain.
  • Pupil is constricted (not dilated), and vision loss is gradual.
  • Not drug-induced.

 

Option B. Retinal artery thrombosis:

 

  • Painless, sudden loss of vision (“curtain coming down”).
  • No eye pain or redness.
  • Fundoscopy shows “cherry-red spot”.

 

Option C. Acute conjunctivitis:

 

  • Causes mild irritation, redness, tearing, and discharge.
  • No severe pain or vision loss.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male complains of painless bilateral visual difficulty that has progressed over the last year. Fundoscopy is shown.  Which of the following would you expect most on visual field examination?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Central scotomas

 

The fundus image shows age-related macular degeneration (ARMD) — a degenerative disease affecting the macula (central retina), responsible for detailed central vision.

 

The macula contains a high density of cone photoreceptors vital for fine visual acuity, color perception, and reading vision.
When it degenerates, central vision is lost, while peripheral vision remains intact, leading to central scotomas on visual field testing.

 

Key Fundus Findings in ARMD:

 

  • Drusen deposits (yellowish spots) in the macular area — extracellular material between Bruch’s membrane and the retinal pigment epithelium.
  • Retinal pigment epithelial changes (mottling or atrophy).
  • May progress to geographic atrophy (dry ARMD) or choroidal neovascularization with hemorrhage/exudate (wet ARMD).

 

Symptoms:

 

  • Painless, gradual central vision loss
  • Metamorphopsia (distorted vision)
  • Difficulty reading, recognizing faces

 

Other Options Explained:

 

Option A. Bitemporal hemianopsia: 

 

  • Caused by optic chiasm compression (e.g., pituitary adenoma).
  • Produces loss of temporal visual fields in both eyes, not central vision loss.

 

Option B. Arcuate scotomas: 

 

  • Seen in glaucoma due to optic nerve damage.
  • Visual loss follows the arcuate nerve fiber pattern in the mid-periphery, sparing the central field initially.

 

Option D. Macular sparing: 

 

  • Occurs in occipital lobe infarcts (posterior cerebral artery occlusion).
  • The macular area is spared due to dual blood supply from the middle cerebral artery, hence peripheral vision loss but preserved central vision — opposite of this case.

questions.text: All of the following are procedures for involutional ectropion except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Palpebral sling operation

 

Palpebral sling operation is not used for involutional ectropion.
It is a surgical procedure performed to correct lagophthalmos (incomplete eyelid closure) or facial nerve palsy, where the upper eyelid is suspended to the frontalis muscle using a sling (usually fascia lata or silicone).


This helps the eyelid close more effectively when the frontalis contracts — not a procedure for lid eversion.

 

Hence, it does not address the horizontal laxity or malposition seen in involutional ectropion.Involutional (senile) ectropion = outward turning of the eyelid margin, usually the lower lid, due to age-related tissue laxity and loss of orbicularis tone.


Main factors:

 

  • Horizontal lid laxity
  • Attenuation of lower lid retractors
  • Medial or lateral canthal tendon laxity

 

Surgical correction therefore focuses on tightening and repositioning of these structures.

 

Other Options:

questions.text: Which of the following is supplied by contralateral nerve nuclei?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Superior rectus

 

Among all the extraocular muscles supplied by the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III), the superior rectus muscle is unique — it receives fibers from the contralateral oculomotor nucleus.

 

That means:

 

  • The right superior rectus is supplied by the left oculomotor nucleus,
  • And the left superior rectus by the right oculomotor nucleus.

 

This crossed innervation occurs because of the decussation of oculomotor fibers within the midbrain before they reach the muscle.

 

Functional Summary:

 

  • Action of superior rectus: Elevation, adduction, and intorsion of the eyeball.
  • The muscle originates from the common tendinous ring and inserts on the superior aspect of the sclera.
  • Its nerve supply comes from the opposite (contralateral) oculomotor nucleus — a key anatomical distinction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inferior rectus:

 

  • Supplied by the ipsilateral oculomotor nucleus.
  • Functions: Depression, adduction, and extorsion of the eye.

 

Option C. Medial rectus:

 

  • Supplied by the ipsilateral oculomotor nucleus.
  • Function: Adduction of the eyeball.

 

Option D. Inferior oblique:

 

  • Supplied by the ipsilateral oculomotor nucleus.
  • Functions: Elevation, abduction, and extorsion of the eye.

questions.text: A patient came from a factory with a chemical injury to the eye a few hours back. Which is the first step in the management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Copious irrigation of eyes

 

In a patient with chemical injury to the eye, the first and most critical step is immediate and copious irrigation of the affected eye — even before taking history or assessing vision.

 

The goal is to remove or dilute the chemical agent as quickly as possible to prevent further penetration and damage to ocular tissues.

 

Why Irrigation Is the First Step:

 

  • Every second counts — the severity of ocular injury depends on contact time of the chemical with the cornea and conjunctiva.
  • Early and thorough irrigation can dramatically reduce long-term damage like corneal scarring, symblepharon, or vision loss.
  • Irrigation should continue until the ocular surface pH normalizes (checked with litmus paper or pH strips).

 

Ideal method:

 

  • Use normal saline, Ringer’s lactate, or even clean tap water if nothing else is available.
  • Eyelids should be everted to wash out trapped particles.
  • Irrigation is continued for at least 30 minutes or until pH = 7.0–7.4.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IOP measurement: Inappropriate as an initial step. Measuring intraocular pressure is delayed until after irrigation and stabilization, as early tonometry may worsen corneal damage or contamination.

 

Option B. Visual acuity: Assessment of visual acuity is important but not before irrigation. Immediate vision testing wastes critical time when chemical damage is ongoing.

 

Option D. Take history: History (chemical type, exposure duration) is important after irrigation. During the acute stage, the focus is on neutralizing and flushing the chemical.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of sudden painless visual loss in his right eye. The patient describes the loss of vision as a veil covering the visual field. He is slightly myopic and had a successful cataract extraction with intraocular lens implantation 3 years ago. The examination finding is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment

 

The image and history are classical of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (RRD) — the most common type of retinal detachment.

 

Key clues from the question:

 

  • Sudden, painless visual loss described as a “veil” or “curtain” → typical of retinal detachment.
  • History of myopia → predisposes to peripheral retinal breaks or lattice degeneration.
  • History of cataract surgery (pseudophakia) → another important risk factor.
  • Ophthalmoscopic finding: Presence of tobacco dust (Shafer’s sign) — pigmented cells floating in the vitreous, indicating a retinal break and release of pigment from the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE).

 

Pathophysiology:

 

In rhegmatogenous retinal detachment, a break or tear in the retina allows liquefied vitreous humor to enter the subretinal space, separating the neurosensory retina from the RPE layer.

 

Common risk factors:

 

  • Myopia
  • Posterior vitreous detachment (age-related)
  • Ocular trauma
  • Previous intraocular surgery (especially cataract extraction)

 

Symptoms:

 

  • Sudden onset of flashes and floaters
  • “Curtain or veil” descending over visual field
  • No pain or redness

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Breaks in Descemet’s membrane: Seen in corneal conditions such as Keratoconus (Vogt’s striae) or birth trauma (Haab’s striae) in congenital glaucoma.
Not related to retinal pathology.

 

Option B. Exudative retinal detachment: Caused by accumulation of fluid beneath the retina without a break, due to inflammation (e.g., Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada), tumors (e.g., choroidal melanoma), or hypertension.
Fundus shows smooth dome-shaped elevation; Shafer’s sign is absent.

 

Option C. Tractional retinal detachment: Occurs from fibrovascular membranes pulling the retina off (e.g., diabetic retinopathy, retinopathy of prematurity).
Gradual, non-rhegmatogenous, and non-sudden in onset.

questions.text: A young child suffering from fever and sore throat began to complain of lacrimation. On examination, follicles were found in the lower palpebral conjunctiva with tender preauricular lymph nodes. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenoviral conjunctivitis

 

The presentation of fever, sore throat, lacrimation, follicles on the lower palpebral conjunctiva, and tender preauricular lymph nodes strongly suggests adenoviral conjunctivitis, specifically a form known as pharyngoconjunctival fever (PCF). PCF is commonly caused by adenovirus, which affects both the respiratory tract and the conjunctiva.

 

Key features:

 

  • Pharyngoconjunctival fever (PCF): Characterized by a triad of pharyngitis (sore throat), conjunctivitis, and fever.
  • Follicular reaction in the conjunctiva and tender preauricular lymphadenopathy are hallmark signs of adenoviral conjunctivitis.
  • PCF often occurs in children and can be associated with outbreaks in close-contact settings like schools or camps.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trachoma: Trachoma can cause follicles in the conjunctiva but is typically chronic and not associated with acute symptoms like fever and sore throat.

 

Option B. Staphylococcal conjunctivitis: This bacterial conjunctivitis presents with purulent discharge rather than follicles and is not associated with systemic symptoms like fever and sore throat.

 

Option D. Phlyctenular conjunctivitis: This condition is associated with hypersensitivity to bacterial antigens, particularly from Mycobacterium tuberculosis, and usually does not present with fever, sore throat, or follicular conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pharyngoconjunctival fever, caused by adenovirus, presents with fever, sore throat, follicular conjunctivitis, and tender preauricular lymph nodes, making adenoviral conjunctivitis the most probable diagnosis.

questions.text: What would you expect to see on the instillation of 1% hydroxyamphetamine into both the eyes of a patient with right-sided postganglionic Horner syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Only left eye dilates

 

This question tests understanding of Horner syndrome localization using pharmacologic testing.

 

Horner syndrome results from interruption of the sympathetic pathway to the eye, leading to:

 

  • Ptosis (loss of Müller’s muscle tone)
  • Miosis (small pupil)
  • Anhidrosis (loss of facial sweating)
  • Apparent enophthalmos

 

The sympathetic pathway to the eye has three neurons:

 

  1. First-order neuron: Hypothalamus → spinal cord (C8–T2, ciliospinal center of Budge)
  2. Second-order neuron: Spinal cord → superior cervical ganglion
  3. Third-order (postganglionic) neuron: Superior cervical ganglion → dilator pupillae muscle via internal carotid plexus and long ciliary nerves

 

2. Hydroxyamphetamine Test (1%):

 

  • Mechanism: Hydroxyamphetamine causes release of stored norepinephrine from postganglionic sympathetic nerve endings, leading to pupil dilation.
  • Therefore, normal sympathetic neurons (intact postganglionic fibers) will respond with dilation.

 

3. Interpretation:

 

 

4. Application to Question:

 

  • Right-sided postganglionic Horner syndrome = damage distal to superior cervical ganglion.
  • After instillation of 1% hydroxyamphetamine:
    • Right eye (postganglionic lesion): No norepinephrine → no dilation
    • Left eye (normal): Normal release → pupil dilates

 

5. Outcome:

 

  • Right eye: No change
  • Left eye: Dilates normally

 

 Therefore: Only left eye dilates

questions.text: Identify the incorrect diagnosis pair:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Orbital pseudotumor

 

 

Among the four neuro-orbital MRI/CT images shown, the second image (labeled as B) does not correspond correctly to the diagnosis of orbital pseudotumor — hence, it’s the incorrect diagnosis pair.

 

Let’s analyze each image and correlate with the correct radiologic diagnosis:

 

  • Expected appearance: Diffuse, ill-defined, enhancing soft-tissue lesion involving extraocular muscles (including tendons), lacrimal gland, or retrobulbar fat; usually unilateral.
  • Actual image shown: Axial orbital CT at level of Eyes with severe fusiform medial rectus enlargement seen in THYROID EYE DISEASE[TED].
  • Diagnosis: TED, thus Incorrect pairing.

 

Other Options:

Option A. Meningioma:

 

  • Image appearance: Extra-axial, dural-based enhancing mass often showing “dural tail sign”.
  • MRI finding: Homogeneous enhancement, broad dural attachment, hyperostosis of adjacent bone may be seen.
  • Diagnosis: Meningioma (Correct match).

 

Option C. Optic nerve glioma:

 

  • Typical MRI features:
    • Fusiform enlargement of the optic nerve
    • Iso- to hypointense on T1, hyperintense on T2
    • Often seen in children and associated with neurofibromatosis type 1.
  • Diagnosis: Optic nerve glioma (Correct match).

 

Option D. Optic nerve meningioma:

 

  • MRI findings:
    • Tram-track sign (enhancing meninges encircling a non-enhancing optic nerve)
    • May show calcification on CT
    • Common in middle-aged women.
  • Diagnosis: Optic nerve meningioma (Correct match).

questions.text: What is the first step in the management of an 18-month-old child with both eyes deviated medially?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Refractive error testing 

 

Refractive error testing is the first step in the evaluation of a child with esotropia (medial deviation of both eyes) to rule out accommodative esotropia — a common cause of convergent squint in infants and toddlers.

 

  • In accommodative esotropia, hypermetropia (farsightedness) causes the child to accommodate excessively to focus, which secondarily increases convergence, leading to medial deviation of eyes.
  • Correcting the refractive error with appropriate hypermetropic glasses often aligns the eyes, confirming the diagnosis.

 

Thus, cycloplegic refraction (after using cycloplegic drops such as atropine or cyclopentolate) is the first diagnostic and therapeutic step.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Forced duction test:

 

  • It is done to differentiate paralytic vs restrictive strabismus by checking for mechanical restriction of ocular movement.
  • It is not the first step — used later when limitation of eye movement is suspected.

 

Option B. Examination under anesthesia:

 

  • Performed when detailed ocular examination is not possible in uncooperative children, e.g., for retinoblastoma, retinopathy of prematurity, or dense cataract.
  • Not required initially in a cooperative 18-month-old for esotropia evaluation.

 

Option D. Examination of fundus:

 

  • Important to rule out retinal or neurological causes of squint, but this is done after refraction and alignment testing.
  • Initial management focuses on detecting and correcting refractive error first.

questions.text: All of the following are used as indicators of a xerophthalmia problem in the community except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Corneal ulcer prevalence >0.1% in 6 months–6 years

 

Corneal scar prevalence >0.05% is not considered an indicator of a current xerophthalmia problem in the community.

 

  • Corneal scars represent past episodes of vitamin A deficiency or trauma; they do not reflect the current status of vitamin A deficiency.
  • Therefore, they are not used as an indicator of an ongoing xerophthalmia problem in public health terms.

questions.text: All of the following organisms can penetrate an intact cornea except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Klebsiella pneumoniae

 

Klebsiella pneumoniaecannot penetrate an intact cornea — it requires a defect or injury in the corneal epithelium to cause infection.

 

  • It is an opportunistic pathogen, typically causing corneal ulcers following trauma, contact lens use, or pre-existing epithelial damage.
  • Hence, it does not have the ability to invade a healthy, intact corneal epithelium.

 

Organisms that can penetrate an intact cornea:

 

  1. Neisseria gonorrhoeae
    → Most invasive organism — can rapidly penetrate healthy corneal epithelium and cause hyperacute keratitis.
  2. Neisseria meningitidis
    → Similar to N. gonorrhoeae, capable of invading intact cornea and causing meningococcal keratitis.
  3. Corynebacterium diphtheriae
    → The diphtheria toxin allows invasion through normal epithelium → causes diphtheritic keratoconjunctivitis.
  4. Haemophilus aegyptius / Haemophilus influenzae
    → Possess proteolytic enzymes and high virulence enabling corneal invasion without trauma.
  5. Listeria monocytogenes
    → Can cross intact corneal epithelium, particularly in immunocompromised hosts or neonates.
  6. Shigella species (especially Shigella dysenteriae)
    → Rare, but reported to penetrate intact cornea due to potent cytotoxins.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the OPD after his wife noted that his eyes appeared different. Medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus.  On physical examination, the right pupil is 3 mm, and the left pupil is 5 mm. When the light in the examination room is dimmed, the anisocoria increases. Which of the following is the most likely location of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Right sympathetic pathway

 

Anisocoria that increases in the dark means the smaller pupil fails to dilate → a sympathetic (dilator) defect in that eye. Here, the right pupil is smaller (3 mm) and doesn’t dilate appropriately in dim light → right-sided sympathetic pathway lesion (Horner syndrome). Associated signs may include mild ptosis and facial anhidrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left oculomotor nerve: Parasympathetic fibers run with CN III; a lesion causes a large, poorly reactive pupil (mydriasis) with anisocoria worse in bright light, plus ptosis and ophthalmoplegia—doesn’t fit this case.

 

Option B. Left parasympathetic pathway: Parasympathetic defects produce a larger pupil that fails to constrict, making anisocoria greater in light and on the affected (left) side—opposite of the findings.

 

Option C. Left optic nerve: An afferent defect (RAPD) alters light responses but does not cause anisocoria; pupil sizes remain symmetric though the direct/consensual responses are asymmetric.

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate born at 28 weeks of gestation had developed respiratory distress syndrome at birth. You want to screen for retinopathy of prematurity. How many weeks from now would you schedule the screening?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4 weeks

 

Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) develops due to abnormal retinal vascular proliferation in premature infants exposed to high oxygen or other stressors.


Screening timing depends on postnatal age and gestational age.

 

Standard recommendation (as per AIIMS / ROP guidelines):

 

  • For infants >28weeks weeks gestation or >1200g g birth weight:
    → First screening at 4 weeks after birth
    Baby born at 28 weeks gestation,
  • Current age: 2 days,
    → So screening is scheduled at 4 weeks of chronological age (i.e., around 32 weeks postmenstrual age).

questions.text: A 35 year old male Anand Jain on slit lamp shows keratic precipitates & aqueous flare in his right eye. No synechiae but a complicated cataract is seen. The probable diagnosis would be:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Heterochromic iridocyclitis of Fuch’s

 

Fuchs’ heterochromic iridocyclitis (FHI) is a chronic, low-grade, non-granulomatous uveitis that typically presents unilaterally in young or middle-aged adults.

 

Key features seen in this case:

 

  • Keratic precipitates: Fine, stellate, diffusely scattered over the endothelium.
  • Aqueous flare present but no posterior synechiae — this absence is characteristic.
  • Complicated cataract (usually posterior subcapsular) is a common complication.
  • Often, heterochromia (difference in iris colour between eyes) may be noted due to iris atrophy, though it can be subtle in dark irides.

 

Hence, the findings point toward Fuchs’ hetero-chromic iridocyclitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intermediate uveitis: Inflammation mainly in the vitreous and peripheral retina (pars plana) — presents with floaters, snowballs, and snow banking, not primarily with KPs and anterior chamber flare.

 

Option B. Heerfordt’s syndrome: A manifestation of sarcoidosis with parotid enlargement, facial nerve palsy, uveitis, and fever. It’s systemic and not limited to the eye with these slit-lamp findings.

 

Option C. Subacute iridocyclitis: Refers to anterior uveitis of intermediate duration (between acute and chronic). Usually has pain, redness, synechiae formation, and more intense inflammation — unlike the mild, quiet anterior chamber in Fuchs’.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about corneal epithelium?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bowman's membrane ends peripherally as Schwalbe's ring

 

This statement is false because Bowman’s membrane does not end as Schwalbe’s ring.

 

  • Schwalbe’s line (or ring) represents the termination of Descemet’s membrane, not Bowman’s membrane.
  • Bowman’s membrane ends peripherally by merging with the connective tissue of the corneal stroma and conjunctiva at the limbus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Descemet’s membrane regenerates: True. Descemet’s membrane (the basement membrane of corneal endothelium) has remarkable regenerative capacity after injury.

 

Option C. Lined by stratified squamous epithelium: True. The corneal surface is covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium — typically 5–6 cell layers thick.

 

Option D. Consists of superficial cells which have microvilli: True. The superficial epithelial cells possess microvilli and microplicae that help in tear film stability and adherence of mucus

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a 2-day history of intermittent dizziness and double vision. She reports double vision whenever she looks to the left. Last summer, she had an episode of weakness in her left leg that resolved spontaneously. Ophthalmologic examination shows weak adduction of the right eye on left lateral gaze. Attempted left lateral gaze results in horizontal nystagmus of the left eye. Convergence testing is normal. This patient most likely has a lesion in which of the following labeled areas of the schematic overview of a transverse section of the midbrain?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) C

 

This patient is presenting with classic features of internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO): impaired adduction of the right eye on left gaze, horizontal nystagmus of the abducting (left) eye, and preserved convergence. Here INO is caused by a lesion in the right medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) of the brainstem.

 

On the labeled schematic of the transverse midbrain provided, the medial longitudinal fasciculus is located in the paramedian region of the dorsal tegmentum, near the midline but ventral/anterior to the periaqueductal gray and dorsal to the superior cerebellar peduncle decussation. 

 

Thus, Option B (C): Correct—site of the medial longitudinal fasciculus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A: Superior colliculus

 

Function: Crucial for visual attention, saccadic (rapid) eye movements, visual reflexes, and orienting the eyes and head toward environmental stimuli.


Pathology:

 

  • Lesions can impair visual tracking, saccades, and visuospatial attention.
  • Involvement seen in progressive supranuclear palsy, Parkinson disease, and certain neurodegenerative disorders with visual hallucinations.

 

Option C. F: Red Nucleus: Lesions of the red nucleus or rubrospinal tract cause contralateral motor symptoms

 

Option D. D: left MLF, causes INO on opposite side as mentioned in question.

choices.text: Ipsilateral paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) and contralateral medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF)
Ipsilateral abducens nucleus and ipsilateral MLF

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with sudden onset diplopia and horizontal gaze palsy. On examination, he cannot move both eyes to the left, and when attempting to look right, the right eye abducts with nystagmus while the left eye fails to adduct. Vertical eye movements are normal. MRI shows a pontine lesion. Which of the following structures are involved?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ipsilateral abducens nucleus and ipsilateral MLF

 

This is one-and-a-half syndrome. The patient has a left horizontal gaze palsy (neither eye can look left) plus an INO on the left (on right gaze, the left eye fails to adduct while the right abducts with nystagmus). This localizes to a pontine tegmental lesion on the left involving the left abducens nucleus (or PPRF) for the gaze palsy and the left MLF for the INO.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ipsilateral PPRF and contralateral MLF: Would produce gaze palsy to the ipsilateral side, but the INO would be on the opposite eye, which doesn’t match the described left adduction failure.

 

Option C. Bilateral abducens nuclei: Would cause bilateral horizontal gaze palsy (neither eye could look horizontally either way), not the combination of unilateral gaze palsy + contralateral abducting nystagmus.

 

Option D. Contralateral PPRF and ipsilateral MLF: A contralateral PPRF lesion would impair gaze away from the side of the MLF lesion; the clinical picture shows both deficits on the same (left) side, so this pairing is inconsistent.

 

Anatomy and Pathophysiology:

 

Horizontal eye movements are coordinated through three key structures:

 

  1. Abducens nucleus (VI nerve nucleus) – controls ipsilateral lateral rectus (abduction).
  2. Medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) – connects the abducens nucleus of one side with the oculomotor nucleus of the opposite side, allowing conjugate gaze.
  3. Paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) – the premotor center that drives both eyes toward one side by activating the abducens nucleus on that side.

 

In One-and-a-Half Syndrome:

 

  • The lesion involves both the abducens nucleus (or PPRF) and the ipsilateral MLF.
  • This combination affects both the conjugate gaze (the “one”) and adduction of the ipsilateral eye (the “half”)
  • vertical gaze pathways lie higher up in the midbrain[Interstitial nucleus of Cajal], not in the pons → therefore, they remain unaffected.

questions.text: Regarding herpes simplex keratitis, all of the following are true except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Steroids are first-line therapy for necrotising stromal keratitis even with epithelial defect

 

This statement is false because topical corticosteroids are contraindicated if an epithelial defect is present in herpes simplex keratitis.

 

In necrotizing stromal keratitis, although steroids are an important part of treatment (to control inflammation), they should never be started until the epithelium has healed — doing so can worsen viral replication, enlarge the ulcer, and may lead to corneal perforation.

 

The correct approach is:

 

  • First: Treat with topical and systemic antivirals (e.g., acyclovir, ganciclovir).
  • Then: Once the epithelium heals, cautious addition of topical steroids may be considered under antiviral cover to reduce stromal inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dendritic ulcer is a typical lesion: True. Herpes simplex epithelial keratitis classically produces a branching dendritic ulcer with terminal bulbs that stain with fluorescein and rose bengal dyes.

 

Option B. Steroids are contraindicated in epithelial keratitis: True. Topical steroids worsen active epithelial HSV infection by enhancing viral replication, leading to geographic ulcers or corneal perforation.

 

Option C. Geographic ulcer is a complication of untreated dendritic ulcer: True. When a dendritic ulcer enlarges or is treated inappropriately with steroids, it can coalesce into a large, amoeboid (geographic) ulcer.

questions.text: A newborn child presents with the following finding in the right eye as shown in the image below. The left eye is normal. What is the ideal age to take this patient up for elective surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6 weeks

 

The image shows a newborn with a unilateral white reflex (leukocoria) — most consistent with a congenital cataract in the right eye.

 

In congenital cataract, timing of surgery is crucial because visual development in infants depends heavily on early and equal visual stimulation of both eyes. Delay can lead to irreversible amblyopia (lazy eye).

 

Ideal Timing of Surgery (as per AIOS/AAO/WHO guidelines):

 

 

Thus, for this unilateral cataract, the ideal age is around 6 weeks.

 

Postoperative Management:

 

  • Optical correction: Contact lens or intraocular lens (IOL) depending on age and surgeon preference.
  • Amblyopia therapy: Patching of normal eye (occlusion therapy).
  • Regular follow-up: For visual rehabilitation and refractive adjustments.

questions.text: A female presents with loss of vision in the right halves of both eyes. Where is the lesion located in the optic pathway?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left optic tract

 

The patient has loss of vision in the right halves of both visual fields — that is right homonymous hemianopia (right temporal field loss in left eye + right nasal field loss in right eye).

 

This indicates a lesion posterior to the optic chiasma, because:

 

  • Pre-chiasmal (optic nerve) lesions cause monocular vision loss.
  • Chiasmal lesions cause bitemporal hemianopia.
  • Post-chiasmal lesions (optic tract, optic radiation, occipital cortex) cause homonymous field defects.

 

In this case, since the right visual field of both eyes is lost, the lesion must be on the left side of the visual pathway — specifically, the left optic tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right optic radiation: Would produce left homonymous hemianopia (loss of left visual fields), not right.

 

Option C. Optic chiasma: Causes bitemporal hemianopia, due to compression of crossing nasal fibers — both temporal fields lost, not homonymous.

 

Option D. Right optic tract: Would cause left homonymous hemianopia, the opposite side of what is described.

 

SUMMARY:

questions.text: Identify the syndrome:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Duane's retraction syndrome type 1

 

The clinical image shows the typical findings of Duane's retraction syndrome type 1:

 

  • There is marked limitation of abduction (outward movement) of the affected eye.
  • Adduction (movement towards the nose) is relatively preserved, but there is narrowing of the palpebral fissure and retraction of the globe on attempted adduction.
  • These findings are most consistent with Duane's retraction syndrome type 1, which is the most common subtype and is characterized by limited abduction, retraction of the globe, and narrowing of the eyelid opening on adduction.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her husband due to a fall. She was walking in her living room when she tripped over an electrical cord. The patient has had several other ground-level falls in the last 6 months but has had no significant injuries. She also gave up driving a year ago following a near-miss motor vehicle accident.  Ophthalmic examination reveals reduced vision in her peripheral visual fields bilaterally and an elevated intraocular pressure. After discussion of treatment options, the patient is initiated on timolol ophthalmic drops. Which of the following structures is the most likely target of this medication?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ciliary epithelium

 

The most likely target of timolol ophthalmic drops is the ciliary epithelium.

 

Timolol is a non-selective beta-blocker that works to lower intraocular pressure by decreasing aqueous humor production in the eye. The site of this action is the ciliary epithelium, where aqueous humor is actively produced. By blocking beta-adrenergic receptors on these cells, timolol reduces aqueous secretion and subsequently lowers intraocular pressure—critical in the management of open-angle glaucoma as seen in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ciliary muscle: Ciliary muscle controls lens shape and accommodation, not aqueous formation.

 

Option C. Pupil sphincter: Pupil sphincter controls pupil size; not related to intraocular pressure.

 

Option D. Trabecular meshwork: Trabecular meshwork is involved in aqueous outflow, not production.

questions.text: A patient presents with endophthalmitis 5 days after cataract surgery. All of the following treatments can be used, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intravenous steroids

 

Not used in the management of acute postoperative endophthalmitis.

 

  • Systemic steroids can worsen infection by suppressing immune response.
  • Only topical steroids may be used after intravitreal antibiotics once the infection starts resolving — never systemic steroids initially.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravitreal antibiotic injection:
Mainstay of treatment — provides high intraocular concentration directly at the site of infection. Common combination:

 

  • Vancomycin (for gram-positive coverage)
  • Ceftazidime or amikacin (for gram-negative coverage)

 

Option C. Pars plana vitrectomy: Used in severe cases or when vision is poor (light perception only). Helps remove infective debris and vitreous exudates.

 

Option D. Topical antibiotics: Supportive therapy for anterior chamber involvement (keratic precipitates, hypopyon).

questions.text: Identify the disease and procedure being performed:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Keratoconus- C3R

 

The image shows a cornea illuminated with green light (from riboflavin dye) and exposed to ultraviolet (UV-A) radiation. A lid speculum keeps the eye open. This appearance is characteristic of Corneal Collagen Cross-Linking (C3R or CXL), a procedure performed to treat keratoconus.

 

Keratoconus is a progressive, non-inflammatory thinning disorder of the cornea that causes it to become conical in shape, leading to:

 

  • Irregular astigmatism
  • Distorted and blurred vision
  • Progressive myopia

 

Typical presentation:

 

  • Young adults with frequent change of glasses
  • Scissoring reflex on retinoscopy
  • Munson’s sign (bulging of lower lid on downgaze)
  • Fleischer’s ring and Vogt’s striae on slit-lamp examination

 

About the Procedure – C3R / Corneal Collagen Cross-Linking:

 

Purpose: To strengthen corneal collagen and halt further thinning.

 

Steps:

 

  1. The corneal epithelium is removed (in the standard "epi-off" technique).
  2. Riboflavin (vitamin B2) drops are applied to saturate the corneal stroma.
  3. The cornea is then irradiated with UV-A light (365 nm) for about 30 minutes.
  4. The UV-A activates riboflavin, creating cross-links between collagen fibers, which increase corneal stiffness and stability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cataract – Phacoemulsification: Not related. This is an intraocular procedure where the lens is emulsified and aspirated using ultrasound.

 

Option B. Corneal Ulcer – Fluorescein staining: Shows green fluorescence of epithelial defects under cobalt blue light but does not involve UV-A exposure or riboflavin.

 

Option D. Myopia – LASIK: Uses an excimer laser to reshape the cornea after creating a corneal flap. It is refractive surgery, not cross-linking.

questions.text: A patient presents with left-sided head tilt which on straightening leads to right hypotropia. This increases on dextroversion and right head tilt. Paralysis of which of the following muscles is involved?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Right superior rectus

 

  • Right hypotropia: Right eye is lower than left in primary position → paralysis of a right depressor or left elevator.
  • Worse on dextroversion: On right gaze (dextroversion), the right eye abducts → the depressors in abduction are right superior rectus and left inferior oblique (acting as elevators and depressors in opposite eyes).
  • Worse on right head tilt: Suggests problem with muscles that normally intort on that side (superior muscles).

 

Step 2 – Apply Bielschowsky Head Tilt Test

 

The head tilt test helps localize cyclovertical muscle palsies.

 

 

Here, diplopia/hypotropia worsens on right head tilt, suggesting weakness of the right superior rectus (the main intorter and elevator in right eye during right tilt).

 

Step 3 – Integrate gaze and head tilt findings

 

 

Hence, all features point to right superior rectus palsy.

questions.text:
In the following enteroviruses, which cause acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis?


1.    Coxsackie A
2.    Coxsackie B
3.    Polio virus
4.    Enterovirus 70
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 4

 

Acute Hemorrhegic Conjunctivitis (AHC) is a highly contagious viral eye infection characterized by sudden onset of:

 

  • Conjunctival redness and chemosis
  • Subconjunctival hemorrhages
  • Pain, photophobia, and foreign-body sensation

 

It spreads rapidly in epidemics, particularly in tropical and coastal regions.

 

Causative Viruses:

 

1. Coxsackievirus A24 variant

 

  • One of the most common causes of AHC worldwide.
  • Belongs to the Enterovirus genus of the Picorna-viridae family.

 

4. Enterovirus 70

 

  • First identified in West Africa (Ghana) in 1969 during an outbreak of AHC.
  • Causes a very rapid epidemic spread through direct contact or fomites.

 

Image below shows Acute Hemorrhagic Conjunctivitis[aka APOLLO conjunctivitis]:

 

 

Other statement:

 

2. Coxsackie B: Causes myocarditis, pleurodynia (Bornholm disease), and aseptic meningitis, but not AHC.

 

3. Poliovirus: Causes paralytic poliomyelitis, not conjunctivitis.

questions.text: A patient presented with unilateral proptosis and bilateral abducent palsy. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cavernous sinus thrombosis

 

Cavernous sinus thrombosis (CST) is a life-threatening condition caused by the formation of a thrombus within the cavernous sinus, often secondary to infection in the danger area of the face, nasal sinuses, or orbit.

 

It is a neuro-ophthalmic emergency that presents with proptosis, chemosis, painful ophthalmoplegia, and cranial nerve palsies.

 

Key Clinical Features:

 

1. Unilateral proptosis

 

  • Due to venous congestion of the orbit from obstruction of the superior ophthalmic vein draining into the cavernous sinus.
  • Initially unilateral but may become bilateral because the two cavernous sinuses communicate.

 

2. Bilateral abducent (6th nerve) palsy

 

  • The abducent nerve (CN VI) runs centrally within the cavernous sinus and is most vulnerable to compression from thrombosis.
  • Involvement is bilateral due to midline proximity.
  • Results in failure of abduction of both eyes → diplopia.

 

3. Associated cranial nerve palsies:

 

  • III, IV, V1, and V2 may also be affected (passing in the lateral wall of the sinus).
  • Causes ophthalmoplegia, ptosis, and sensory loss over the forehead and cheek.

 

4. Systemic signs:

 

  • Fever, headache, vomiting, and signs of sepsis.
  • Often secondary to facial furuncle, sinusitis, or orbital cellulitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinoblastoma: Occurs in children, presents with leukocoria and strabismus, not with cranial nerve palsies or proptosis in adults.

 

Option B. Orbital pseudotumor: Inflammatory lesion of the orbit; causes painful proptosis and restricted ocular movements, but does not cause bilateral abducent palsy.

 

Option C. Orbital cellulitis: Can cause unilateral proptosis and ophthalmoplegia, but bilateral cranial nerve involvement (especially both VI nerves) is unusual and suggests spread to the cavernous sinus.

choices.text: Blue-yellow defects are seen in retinal diseases like CSR and macular edema
Red-green defects are seen in optic nerve lesions
Congenital dyschromatopsia is more common in males

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding acquired color vision defects except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tritanopia is the most common congenital color vision defect

 

This statement is false because tritanopia (blue–yellow colour blindness) is actually rare among congenital colour vision defects.

 

The most common congenital colour vision defect is a red–green defect, usually protanopia or deuteranopia, both of which are X-linked recessive and therefore much more common in males.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Blue-yellow defects are seen in retinal diseases like CSR and macular edema: True. Acquired blue–yellow (tritan) defects are typical of retinal diseases, especially those affecting the macula (e.g., central serous retinopathy, macular edema). They result from dysfunction of the short-wavelength (S-cone) system.

 

Option B. Red-green defects are seen in optic nerve lesions: True. Acquired red–green dyschromatopsia is a hallmark of optic nerve and optic pathway lesions, such as optic neuritis or toxic/nutritional optic neuropathy. It reflects early involvement of the papillomacular bundle.

 

Option C. Congenital dyschromatopsia is more common in males: True. Congenital red–green defects are X-linked recessive, hence predominant in males and rare in females.

questions.text: A patient with 1.5D myopia undergoes streak retinoscopy. The patient is seated one meter from the light source and is asked to fixate on a distant object as the retinoscopy is performed. With respect to the movement of the plane mirror in the retinoscope, the red reflex in the eye exhibits:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Movement against the plane

 

  • In retinoscopy for a myopic eye, the red reflex moves opposite (against) to the movement of the retinoscope's plane mirror (streak).
  • Here, the patient has 1.5D myopia and is seated 1 meter from the light source (the working distance of 1 meter corresponds to +1D lens power).
  • For myopia greater than the working distance lens power, the reflex moves “against” the movement of the streak.
  • If the refractive error equals exactly the working distance (neutral point), the reflex will show no movement.
  • For hyperopia, the reflex moves “with” the plane of the retinoscope.

 

Therefore, since this patient has 1.5D myopia and the examination is at 1 meter distance, the reflex will show an against movement with respect to the plane mirror

questions.text: An 85-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to worsening eye pain. Physical examination shows scattered vesicles on the left side of the forehead and nose and on the left upper and lower eyelids. Fluorescein staining is shown below. Which of the following pathogens is most likely responsible for this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Varicella-zoster virus

 

Vesicular rash confined to the V1 (ophthalmic) dermatome—forehead, eyelids, and tip/side of the nose (Hutchinson sign)—with ocular pain and the fluorescein pattern of branching “pseudodendrites” without terminal bulbs is classic for herpes zoster ophthalmicus, due to reactivation of VZV. It can cause keratitis, uveitis, and elevated IOP; treat urgently with systemic antivirals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenovirus: Typically causes epidemic keratoconjunctivitis with watery discharge, follicular conjunctivitis, preauricular lymphadenopathy, and later subepithelial infiltrates—no dermatomal vesicles and no zoster pseudo-dendrites.

 

 

Option B. Candida albicans: Causes fungal keratitis, often after vegetative trauma or with contact lenses/immunosuppression. Slit-lamp shows feathery stromal infiltrates and possible satellite lesions, not dermatomal skin vesicles.

 

 

Option C. Herpes simplex virus: HSV epithelial keratitis shows true dendritic ulcers with terminal bulbs that stain brightly with fluorescein and rose bengal, usually without a dermatomal vesicular rash. Here, the cutaneous V1 involvement points to VZV, not HSV.

questions.text: A patient presented with foreign body sensation, redness, and excessive watering from the right eye for 15 days after a twig brushed against his eye. Examination is shown below. Which among the following is the appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Amphotericin B drops

 

The image and history are classical for fungal keratitis, most likely caused by filamentous fungi such as Fusarium or Aspergillus.

 

Key Clinical Clues:

 

  1. History of vegetative trauma (twig injury) – a hallmark risk factor for fungal keratitis.
  2. Symptoms: Pain, redness, watering, and foreign body sensation persisting for days to weeks.
  3. Slit-lamp findings:
    • Dry, gray-white corneal ulcer with feathery margins
    • Satellite lesions
    • Possible hypopyon (pus in anterior chamber)
    • Minimal discharge compared to bacterial ulcers

 

These findings strongly suggest fungal corneal ulcer, not bacterial or viral.

 

Treatment:

 

Topical antifungal agents are the mainstay of therapy.

 

  • First-line drug: Amphotericin B (0.15%) – effective for Candida and filamentous fungi.
  • Alternative: Natamycin 5% eye drops (especially for Fusarium species).
  • Adjuncts: Topical voriconazole or itraconazole may be used for resistant infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acyclovir ointment: Used for herpes simplex keratitis (dendritic ulcer). HSV ulcers are linear/branching, not dry or feathery.

 

Option B. Propamidine isethionate: Used for Acanthamoeba keratitis, typically in contact lens wearers with severe pain disproportionate to signs, not after vegetative trauma.

 

Option C) Hydrocortisone ointment: Steroids are contraindicated in corneal ulcers (especially fungal), as they worsen infection and delay healing.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with lagophthalmos, orbicularis oculi palsy, and loss of corneal sensation. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mycobacterium leprae

 

Based on the ocular manifestations of leprosy, Mycobacterium leprae is the most likely causative organism.

 

  • Ocular symptoms include:
    • Lagophthalmos (inability to close the eyelids) due to the involvement of the zygomatic branch of the facial nerve. Other causes of lagophthalmos include extreme proptosis (bulging of the eyes) and symblepharon (adhesion of the eyelids to the eyeball).
    • Corneal anesthesia is due to the involvement of the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve, which innervates the cornea.
    • Corneal ulceration
    • Episcleritis
    • Iris atrophy
  • In addition, patients may present with:
    • Cataract,
    • Glaucoma,
    • Madarosis (loss of eyelashes or eyebrows)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Acanthamoeba castellanii

 

  • Acanthamoeba castellanii can cause acanthamoeba keratitis.
  • Symptoms include pain, lacrimation, photophobia, and foreign body sensation.
  • Results from direct corneal contact with infected material.
  • Contact lens users are at an increased risk.
  • Radial keratoneuritis is pathognomonic.

 

Option C: Onchocerca volvulus

 

  • Onchocerca volvulus causes onchocerciasis, commonly seen in African countries.
  • Symptoms include sclerosing keratitis, uveitis, chorioretinitis, and optic neuritis.
  • Ultimately, it can lead to optic atrophy.

 

Option D: Chlamydia A to C

 

  • Chlamydia trachomatis serovars A, B, Ba, and C are responsible for hyperendemic (blinding) trachoma.
  • The source of infection is infected conjunctival discharge.
  • If there is no secondary bacterial infection, symptoms include lacrimation, scanty mucoid discharge, and foreign body sensation.
  • Conjunctival congestion and follicles, papillary hyperplasia, Herbert follicles (seen in the limbal area), and progressive pannus are the characteristic features.
  • Serovars D to K cause neonatal and adult inclusion conjunctivitis.
  • Neonates present with conjunctival discharge, chemosis, and swollen lids.
  • Adult inclusion conjunctivitis is more commonly seen in sexually active adults and presents with foreign body sensation, mild photophobia, and mucopurulent discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lagophthalmos, orbicularis oculi palsy, and loss of corneal sensation—are indicative of neurogenic involvement, which is characteristic of leprosy, caused by Mycobacterium leprae.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman comes to the office due to transient visual changes that are characterized by "loss of vision for a minute" and commonly precipitated by bending forward or lifting objects. During the last 3 months, she has had persistent headaches that she attributes to migraines. The patient takes over-the-counter analgesics as needed. Blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg and pulse is 72/min and regular. BMI is 32.4 kg/m2. Funduscopic findings of the left eye are shown in the image below, with similar findings in the right eye. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the observed funduscopic findings in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Elevated intracranial pressure

 

The fundus image shows bilateral optic disc swelling with blurred margins and hyperemia, consistent with papilledema.

 

The clinical history and findings also support this diagnosis.

 

Stepwise reasoning:

 

1. Clinical clues from the case:

 

  • Transient visual obscurations (brief, seconds-long loss of vision)
  • Triggered by bending forward or straining → transient rise in intracranial pressure
  • Headache (persistent, often worse in morning)
  • Obese woman of childbearing age (BMI 32.4 kg/m²)

 

These features are typical of Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension (IIH / Pseudotumor cerebri).

 

2. Fundus findings:

 

  • Bilateral swollen optic discs with:
    • Elevated, hyperemic discs
    • Blurred margins
    • Loss of physiologic cup
    • Engorged veins and flame-shaped hemorrhages

 

This appearance is classic for papilledema, which results from elevated intracranial pressure transmitted to the optic nerve sheath.

 

Pathophysiology:

 

  • Increased intracranial pressure (ICP) → transmitted via subarachnoid space surrounding the optic nerve → axoplasmic flow stasis at the optic disc → disc swelling.
  • Vision usually normal initially; transient visual loss may occur due to papilledema-related ischemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Choroidal inflammation: Seen in choroiditis, causing focal lesions or exudative retinal detachment, not optic disc swelling.

 

Option C. Elevated intraocular pressure: Causes glaucomatous optic neuropathy with optic disc cupping (excavation), not disc swelling.

 

Option D. Optic nerve inflammation (optic neuritis): Presents with painful, unilateral vision loss, afferent pupillary defect, and mild disc edema (if anterior). Here, disc edema is bilateral, painless, and symmetrical, typical of papilledema.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with leukocoria in the left eye. The CT is shown below. The most likely mutated gene is on the same chromosome as which of the following genes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) BRCA2

 

The image shows a CT orbit/brain with calcified intraocular mass in a child presenting with leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) — classic for retinoblastoma.

 

Now, relating to the question:

 

They ask:

 

“The most likely mutated gene is on the same chromosome as which of the following genes?”

 

The RB1 gene is located on chromosome 13q14,
and the BRCA2 gene is also located on chromosome 13q12.3.

 

Genetic basis:

 

  • Caused by mutation of the RB1 gene (a tumor suppressor gene)
  • Chromosomal location: 13q14

 

Loss of both RB1 alleles (Knudson’s "two-hit" hypothesis) → loss of cell cycle control at G1-S checkpoint, leading to uncontrolled proliferation of retinal cells.

 

Key points:

 

Retinoblastoma

 

  • Most common primary intraocular malignancy in children
  • Presentation: Leukocoria, strabismus, proptosis, or orbital mass
  • CT finding: Intraocular calcification (diagnostic hallmark)

choices.text: External hordeolum is an acute inflammation of the Zeis gland
Meibomian gland is a modified apocrine gland
Internal hordeolum is an acute suppurative inflammation of meibomian gland
Chalazion is a chronic granulomatous inflammation of the meibornian gland

questions.text: Which of the following is false:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Meibomian gland is a modified apocrine gland

 

The Meibomian gland is a specialized form of sebaceous gland located in the tarsal plates of the eyelids. Unlike typical sebaceous glands associated with hair follicles, Meibomian glands open directly onto the eyelid margin and secrete an oily, lipid-rich substance called meibum. This secretion plays a crucial role in eye health by forming the superficial lipid layer of the tear film, which reduces evaporation of the aqueous component of tears and helps maintain corneal hydration and comfort.

 

Histologically, Meibomian glands are large, lobulated holocrine glands. Holocrine secretion means that the glandular cells mature and disintegrate as part of the secretion process, releasing their entire content as meibum

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. External hordeolum is an acute inflammation of the glands of Zeis or Moll:

 

  • External hordeolum, commonly called a stye, is an acute localized infection—usually caused by Staphylococcus aureus—affecting the glands of Zeis (sebaceous glands at the base of eyelashes) or Moll (modified sweat glands near eyelashes).
  • Clinically, it presents as a painful, red swelling at the eyelid margin with a visible pustule or abscess near an eyelash follicle.
  • Because these glands are superficial, the abscess is visible without everting the eyelid.

 

Option C. Internal hordeolum is an acute suppurative inflammation of the Meibomian gland:

 

  • Internal hordeolum arises from infection of the deeper Meibomian glands, which are modified sebaceous glands embedded in the tarsal plate of the eyelid.
  • It causes tender, erythematous swelling of the eyelid that is often less well defined because the glands lie beneath muscle and connective tissue.
  • The abscess is visualized only when the eyelid is everted.
  • Like external hordeolum, it is primarily caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

 

Option D. Chalazion is a chronic granulomatous inflammation of the Meibomian gland:

 

  • Chalazion develops from chronic obstruction and inflammation (not infection) of the Meibomian gland’s ducts.
  • It manifests as a painless, firm nodule within the eyelid due to granulomatous inflammation involving histiocytes and multinucleated giant cells.
  • Histologically called a lipogranuloma, the inflammation is a response to leaked glandular lipids provoking this chronic reaction.
  • Chalazion often develops weeks after an internal hordeolum or meibomian gland dysfunction.

questions.text:
Which of these is a true statement? 

 

  1. Ferry’s Line - corneal epithelial iron line at the edge of filtering blebs 
  2. Stockers Line - Corneal epithelial iron line at the edge of pterygium 
  3. Hudson-Stahli line - visible all around the base of cone in Keratoconus 
  4. Fleischer’s ring - Horizontal corneal epithelial iron line’ at the inferior one third of cornea due to aging
  5. Coat’s white ring - A form of iron deposit at the level of Bowman’s layer of cornea
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 5

 

True Statements:

 

1. Ferry’s Line:


A corneal epithelial iron deposition line that forms at the edge of filtering blebs following glaucoma filtering surgery.
It is due to tear film stagnation and iron deposition from tears.
Seen as a fine brownish line adjacent to the surgical bleb.

 

 

2. Stocker’s Line:


An iron line located at the advancing edge of a pterygium, deposited beneath the corneal epithelium.


Occurs due to tear pooling and chronic irritation caused by the pterygium head.
 

It indicates a slowly progressive pterygium.

 

 

5. Coats’ White Ring:


Appears as a small, oval or circular superficial white opacity at the level of Bowman’s membrane.


It represents iron and fibrous tissue deposition secondary to a healed metallic foreign body injury.


It is a residual, non-progressive lesion and does not affect vision.

 

 

False Statements:

 

3. Hudson–Stähli Line:
 

A horizontal iron line seen in the lower third of the cornea, usually in elderly individuals.
 

It results from tear pooling near the lower lid margin.
 

It is not associated with keratoconus and is unrelated to the cone base.

 

 

4. Fleischer’s Ring:


An iron deposition ring surrounding the base of the cone in keratoconus, best seen with cobalt blue light.
 

It forms due to tear stagnation at the cone margin.
 

It is not a horizontal aging line, which differentiates it from Hudson–Stähli line.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman with a history of Bell’s palsy presents with dryness in her left eye. Ocular examination shows mild punctate epithelial defects and corneal dryness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Exposure keratopathy

 

This 21-year-old woman has a history of Bell’s palsy (facial nerve VII palsy) and now presents with dryness and punctate epithelial defects in the same eye — classic for exposure keratopathy.

 

Pathophysiology:

 

  • Bell’s palsy causes paralysis of the orbicularis oculi muscle, leading to incomplete eyelid closure (lagophthalmos).
  • This results in corneal exposure, especially of the inferior and temporal cornea, leading to drying and epithelial breakdown.
  • The tear film evaporates more quickly, causing punctate epithelial erosions and exposure keratitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Neurotrophic keratopathy: Occurs due to loss of corneal sensation (CN V lesion), leading to painless epithelial defects and non-healing ulcers.
In Bell’s palsy, the issue is exposure, not sensory loss.

 

Option C. Mooren ulcer: An idiopathic peripheral corneal ulceration due to autoimmune cause, usually painful and progressive — not seen in this setting.

 

Option D. Herpes simplex keratitis: Presents with pain, dendritic ulcers with terminal bulbs on fluorescein staining.


Here, the lesions are punctate and due to dryness, not viral infection.

questions.text: A 21-year-old student presents with ocular redness, foreign body sensation, and excessive tearing, following the use of a contact lens. An interface contrast microscopy from his corneal scraping is shown below. Which of the following is false regarding the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Topical Steroids

 

The image shows the classic double-walled cyst of Acanthamoeba on microscopy (polygonal or star-shaped with a wrinkled outer wall and a smooth inner wall).

 

The clinical setting — contact lens user with redness, pain, tearing, and foreign-body sensation — strongly suggests Acanthamoeba keratitis.

 

Pathophysiology:

 

  • Acanthamoeba is a free-living protozoan found in soil, tap water, and swimming pools.
  • It infects the cornea, especially in contact lens users who clean lenses with tap water or wear them while swimming.
  • The infection is characterized by disproportionately severe pain, ring-shaped stromal infiltrate, and poor response to antibiotics.

 

Treatment Overview:

 

Main goals: Kill both the trophozoite and cystic forms of Acanthamoeba.

 

  1. Topical anti-amoebic agents (mainstay):
    • Polyhexamethylene biguanide (PHMB 0.02%)
    • Chlorhexidine 0.02–0.06%
    • Can be combined with propamidine isethionate (Brolene) or neomycin.
  2. Debridement of epithelium:
    • Helps in increasing drug penetration to deeper corneal layers.
  3. Oral NSAIDs:
    • Used for pain control and inflammation.

 

Why Option (a) is False:

 

Topical steroids are contraindicated in Acanthamoeba keratitis, especially in the early or active phase, because:

 

  • They enhance trophozoite proliferation.
  • They suppress local immune response, worsening infection.
  • They may delay healing and mask symptoms.

 

Steroids are used only after infection control (under anti-amoebic coverage) in select cases of immune-mediated inflammation.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to painless, progressive visual impairment. The patient was diagnosed with sexually acquired HIV infection 4 years ago. He was previously started on antiretroviral therapy but has been noncompliant with his prescribed medications. Funduscopy reveals the findings seen in the image below. Which of the following medications is the best initial therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ganciclovir

 

The fundus image shows fluffy yellow-white retinal lesions with hemorrhagic borders — the classic “pizza pie” or “cottage cheese with ketchup” appearance, diagnostic of Cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis.

 

This is the most common ocular opportunistic infection in AIDS patients with CD4 counts <50 cells/mm³.

 

Key features of CMV retinitis:

 

Etiology:


Reactivation of latent Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection in immunocompromised individuals (particularly AIDS patients).

 

Clinical presentation:

 

  • Painless, progressive visual loss
  • Floaters and blurred vision
  • Often bilateral, but may start in one eye
  • No eye pain or redness (helps differentiate from HSV or VZV retinitis)

 

Fundus findings:

 

  • Retinal necrosis with hemorrhage and exudates (gives “pizza pie” or “cheese and ketchup” appearance)
  • Involvement typically starts in the posterior pole and may spread peripherally.

 

Treatment:

 

First-line therapy:


→ Ganciclovir (IV or oral) or Valganciclovir (oral prodrug)

 

Alternative / adjunct options:

 

  • Foscarnet or Cidofovir (for ganciclovir-resistant cases)
  • Intravitreal ganciclovir or foscarnet for severe sight-threatening lesions
  • Resume or initiate antiretroviral therapy (ART) to restore immune function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acyclovir: Used for HSV and VZV infections, not effective against CMV.

 

Option B. Amphotericin B: Used for fungal infections (e.g., Candida, Aspergillus, Cryptococcus), not viral infections.

 

Option C. Clarithromycin: Used for Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infections in AIDS, not for CMV.

questions.text: A neonate with leukocoria and strabismus is found to have following USG finding. With which congenital disorder is this condition most commonly associated?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Patau syndrome

 

The ultrasound image shows a retrolental echogenic membrane with a persistent vascular stalk , consistent with Persistent Hyperplastic Primary Vitreous (PHPV).

 

PHPV is a congenital developmental anomaly due to failure of regression of the hyaloid artery and primary vitreous.

 

It presents with leukocoria, microphthalmos, and cataract in a neonate.

 

Most commonly associated with Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Down syndrome: Associated mainly with Brushfield spots, cataract, and keratoconus (in ophthalmic conditions), not with PHPV.

 

Option B. Tuberous sclerosis: Shows retinal astrocytomas (mulberry lesions), not persistent fetal vasculature.

 

Option D. Osteosarcoma: Associated with retinoblastoma (not PHPV), particularly with germline RB1 gene mutation.

 

NOTE:

 

PHPV is usually Unilateral and doesn't calcify, whereas Retinoblastoma mostly exists bilateral and shows calcification in Globe.
