questions.text: A 75-year-old woman attends the emergency department with nausea and vomiting. She says that her right eye is painful and red. Vision is reduced. She is longsighted and wears glasses for near and distance vision. She is generally fit. There is no family history of medical problems. On examination the emergency doctor finds the vision to be reduced to counting fingers in the right eye. The eye is red, the cornea appears cloudy and edematous, and the pupil is oval and dilated on the affected side. No view of the fundus is obtained. What are the immediate and definitive treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intravenous Acetazolamide, and Nd:YAG 1064nm laser Iridotomy

 

his is a classic presentation of acute angle-closure glaucoma (AACG) — an ophthalmic emergency.

 

Step 1  Identifying the Diagnosis

 

Key clinical features:

 

  • Elderly, hypermetropic (farsighted) woman → anatomically predisposed (shallow anterior chamber).
  • Sudden onset of:
    • Severe ocular pain and redness
    • Blurred vision, halos around lights
    • Nausea and vomiting (due to vagal stimulation)
  • Exam findings:
    • Cloudy cornea (from corneal edema)
    • Mid-dilated, fixed, vertically oval pupil
    • Markedly raised intraocular pressure (IOP) (often >40–50 mmHg)
    • No fundus view due to corneal edema

 

All of these confirm acute primary angle-closure glaucoma.

 

Step 2 – Immediate (Emergency) Treatment

 

Goal: Rapidly reduce intraocular pressure (IOP) to prevent permanent optic nerve damage.

 

Immediate measures:

 

  1. Intravenous Acetazolamide (500 mg) – carbonic anhydrase inhibitor
    → Decreases aqueous humor production and rapidly lowers IOP.
  2. Topical beta-blocker (e.g., timolol) – reduces aqueous production.
  3. Topical pilocarpine (after IOP control) – causes miosis to open the angle.
  4. Hyperosmotic agents (e.g., IV mannitol) – in severe cases.

 

Step 3 – Definitive Treatment

 

Once the acute attack is controlled and corneal clarity improves:

 

Definitive procedure:

 

  • Laser peripheral iridotomy (LPI) using Nd:YAG 1064 nm laser (preferred)
    → Creates a small hole in the peripheral iris, allowing aqueous to flow directly from posterior to anterior chamber, relieving pupillary block.
    → Usually performed bilaterally since the other eye is at risk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Topical pilocarpine and Nd:YAG 532 nm laser capsulotomy:

 

  • Capsulotomy is for posterior capsule opacification after cataract surgery, not for glaucoma.
  • Pilocarpine should be given after IOP reduction, not as an initial step when the iris is ischemic.

 

Option B. Intravenous Acetazolamide and Femtosecond laser iridotomy:

 

  • Femtosecond laser is used in refractive or cataract surgery, not standard for angle-closure management.

 

Option D. Topical Beta-Blockers and Trabeculectomy:

 

  • Trabeculectomy is a surgical procedure for chronic glaucoma, not the acute form.

choices.text: Toxic anterior segment syndrome; No organism

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a previous history of cataract surgery two weeks back presented with diminution of vision, visual acuity 5/60, anterior chamber cells, vitreous haze with no fundus details visible. What is the diagnosis and the organism causing it?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endophthalmitis; Staphylococcus

 

This 60-year-old man presents 2 weeks after cataract surgery with marked visual loss, anterior chamber cells, and vitreous haze—with no fundus view.


This clinical picture is classic for postoperative endophthalmitis, an emergency intraocular infection.

 

Postoperative Endophthalmitis Definition:


Endophthalmitis is a severe inflammation/infection of the intraocular cavities (aqueous + vitreous), usually due to bacterial contamination during or after intraocular surgery.

 

Timing:

 

  • Acute form: Within 6 weeks of surgery (typically 1–2 weeks).
  • Chronic/delayed form: After 6 weeks

 

Causative Organisms:

 

A. Acute postoperative endophthalmitis:

 

  • Most common organism:Staphylococcus epidermidis (coagulase-negative staphylococcus)
  • Others: Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus species, Pseudomonas aeruginosa (fulminant course)

 

B. Delayed (chronic) postoperative endophthalmitis:

 

  • Propionibacterium acnes (now Cutibacterium acnes)
  • Presents weeks–months later, with milder inflammation.

 

Hence, in this case (2 weeks post-op, acute course), the most likely organism is Staphylococcus species.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Toxic anterior segment syndrome (TASS):

 

  • Sterile postoperative inflammation caused by toxic chemicals (e.g., detergents, preservatives).
  • Occurs within 12–48 hours after surgery, not 2 weeks later.
  • No organism involved, resolves with steroids.

 

Option B. Endophthalmitis; Propionibacterium cutis:

 

  • Propionibacterium acnes (cutis) causes chronic delayed-onset endophthalmitis (6+ weeks post-surgery).
  • Presents more indolently, not acute as in this case.

 

Option D. Sympathetic ophthalmia; Mucormycosis:

 

  • Sympathetic ophthalmia = bilateral granulomatous uveitis after penetrating injury, not after cataract surgery.
  • Mucormycosis affects immunocompromised patients with rhino-orbital involvement, not this presentation.

questions.text: What is the action of the muscle supplied by the structure marked A. in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intorsion, abduction, depression 

 

The structure labeled A in the image corresponds to the Trochlear nerve (Cranial Nerve IV) — the only cranial nerve that emerges dorsally from the brainstem and innervates a single extraocular muscle: the Superior Oblique muscle.

 

Muscle Supplied:

 

Superior Oblique muscle

 

Nerve supply:


→ Trochlear nerve (CN IV)

 

Actions of the Superior Oblique Muscle:

 

  1. Primary action – Intorsion (medial rotation)
    • Rotates the top of the eyeball toward the nose.
    • Due to its insertion behind the equator of the eyeball.
  2. Secondary action – Depression
    • When the eye is adducted, the superior oblique acts as a depressor.
    • This distinguishes it from the inferior rectus, which depresses the abducted eye.
  3. Tertiary action – Abduction
    • Slightly moves the eye laterally, as the tendon passes through the trochlea to the superior posterolateral aspect of the globe.

 

Summary Table: [SIN RAD-mnemonic]

 

 

Mnemonic:

 

SO4 LR6 O3

 

  • SO (Superior Oblique) → CN IV (Trochlear)
  • LR (Lateral Rectus) → CN VI (Abducens)
  • All others → CN III (Oculomotor)

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the office due to double vision. The patient first experienced difficulty focusing her eyes while at work yesterday. On awakening this morning, her symptoms had progressed to frank diplopia. A complete physical examination is performed, including a full neurologic assessment. Shining light into the patient's right eye causes constriction of her right pupil, but not the left pupil. Shining light into her left eye causes constriction of only her right pupil. Which of the following additional physical examination findings is likely to be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Drooping of the left eyelid

 

1. Interpreting the pupillary findings

 

  • Light in right eye → right pupil constricts (direct) but left pupil does not constrict (no consensual response).
  • Light in left eye → right pupil constricts (consensual) but left pupil does not constrict (no direct response).

 

This pattern means:

 

  • The afferent limb (optic nerve, CN II) is intact in both eyes, because shining light in either eye produces some pupillary constriction (in the right eye).
  • The efferent limb (oculomotor nerve, CN III) to the left eye is damaged, because the left pupil never constricts.

 

Thus, the lesion is an efferent (parasympathetic) defect of the left oculomotor nerve.

 

Left CN III palsy leads to:

 

  • Ptosis (levator palpebrae paralysis)
  • "Down and out" eye position (unopposed lateral rectus and superior oblique action)
  • Dilated pupil and loss of light reflex (sphincter pupillae paralysis)
  • Diplopia due to misalignment

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Absence of the left corneal reflex:

 

  • The afferent limb of the corneal reflex is trigeminal nerve (ophthalmic division, V1).
  • The efferent limb is facial nerve (VII) for eyelid closure.
  • CN III is not involved in this reflex.
    → So this would not occur in an oculomotor nerve lesion.

 

Option C. Inability to close the left eye:

 

  • Controlled by orbicularis oculi muscle (supplied by facial nerve, CN VII).
  • In CN III palsy, the eye cannot open fully (ptosis), not close.
    → So this suggests a facial nerve lesion, not oculomotor.

 

Option D. Inward deviation of the left eye:

 

  • An inwardly deviated (esotropic) eye occurs in abducens (CN VI) palsy**, due to loss of the lateral rectus muscle**.
  • In CN III palsy, the eye is outwardly deviated (exotropic) due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique.

questions.text: Identify the correct pair:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Foster Fuch spots-Myopia

 

Let’s analyze each option carefully:

 

  • Foster–Fuchs spots are pigmented scars at the macula caused by choroidal neovascularization and subretinal hemorrhage in pathologic (degenerative) myopia.
  • They appear as small, dark gray or black spots near the fovea and represent RPE hyperplasia after healing of subretinal hemorrhage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vogt’s triad – Open angle glaucoma:
Incorrect.

 

  • Vogt’s triad actually belongs to Keratoconus, not glaucoma.
  • It includes:
    1. Vogt’s striae (fine vertical lines in Descemet’s membrane)
    2. Fleischer’s ring (iron ring at the base of the cone)
    3. Oil droplet reflex on retinoscopy
  • These findings are seen in Keratoconus, a progressive corneal ectasia.

 

Option B. Vogt’s striae – Congenital buphthalmos:
 Incorrect.

  • Vogt’s striae are stress lines in the deep stroma and Descemet’s membrane seen in Keratoconus, not in congenital buphthalmos.
  • They disappear with gentle pressure on the globe.

 

Option C. Shield ulcer – Atopic dermatitis:
Incorrect.

 

  • Shield ulcers are superficial corneal ulcers seen in Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (VKC), which can occur in patients with atopy or allergic predisposition 
  • Its Shield Cataract which are associated with Atopic Dermatitis.

questions.text: Which of the following can occur in a patient with prolactinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Superior quadrantanopia

 

  • Prolactinomas are pituitary tumors which can grow large enough (macroprolactinomas) to compress the optic chiasm, located just above the sella turcica.
  • The optic chiasm anatomy with crossing fibers is organized such that the inferior retinal fibers (which receive superior visual field information) cross in the anterior chiasm.
  • Compression of the inferior fibers in the optic chiasm may result in superior visual field defects, including superior quadrantanopia. This is less common than the classic bitemporal hemianopia but can occur depending on tumor location and chiasmal anatomy.
  • Visual field defects from prolactinomas are usually bitemporal hemianopias but can vary in pattern.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inferior quadrantanopia:

 

  • Inferior quadrantanopia usually results from lesions further back in the visual pathway, especially the temporal lobe (Meyer's loop) or parietal lobe.
  • It is not a typical finding in prolactinoma because these tumours do not compress these posterior visual pathways.

 

Option C. Priapism:

 

  • Priapism (prolonged painful erection) is not a typical feature associated with prolactinoma.
  • Prolactinomas often cause hypogonadism via prolactin-induced inhibition of gonadotropin-releasing hormone, leading to decreased libido and erectile dysfunction, the opposite effect of priapism.

 

Option D. Failure of lactation:

 

  • Prolactin is the hormone responsible for stimulating milk production.
  • Prolactinomas cause elevated prolactin levels leading to galactorrhoea and sometimes inappropriate lactation or failure of lactation due to disrupted hormonal balance.
  • However, the term "failure of lactation" is usually not associated with prolactinoma; instead, excess prolactin causes milk production outside of pregnancy or lactation.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

 

1. Microaneurysms appear as hyperfluorescent branching pattern on FFA

2. Hard exudates are found in outer plexiform layer 

3. Normal A:V ratio is 3:2 at the fundus 

4. IOC for best disease is EOG
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 4

 

2. Hard exudates are found in outer plexiform layer: Correct.
 

Hard exudates are lipid and proteinaceous deposits that leak from damaged retinal vessels.
 

They accumulate in the outer plexiform layer (Henle’s layer) of the retina and appear as yellowish, waxy deposits arranged in a circinate pattern around microaneurysms.

.

4. IOC for Best disease is EOG: Correct.
 

Best vitelliform macular dystrophy shows a classic “egg-yolk” lesion in the macula.
 

The investigation of choice (IOC) is Electrooculography (EOG), which shows a reduced Arden ratio (<1.5) due to retinal pigment epithelium dysfunction.
ERG (Electroretinogram) is usually normal.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

1. Microaneurysms appear as hyperfluorescent branching pattern on FFA: Incorrect.
 

Microaneurysms appear as small, focal hyperfluorescent dots (not branching) on fluorescein fundus angiography (FFA), typically seen in early phases of diabetic retinopathy.
A branching pattern would suggest retinal or choroidal neovascularization, not microaneurysms.

 

3. Normal A:V ratio is 3:2 at the fundus: Incorrect.

 

In a normal retinal examination, the artery-to-vein (A:V) ratio is approximately 2:3.

 

This ratio is clinically important — arteriolar narrowing in hypertension or retinopathy alters it to 1:3 or less

questions.text: A neonate was found to have the following finding on routine examination of the eye. All of the following may be differentials except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Congenital glaucoma

 

Congenital glaucoma typically presents with epiphora (watering), photophobia, and blepharospasm due to elevated intraocular pressure.
Characteristic ocular findings include corneal haze, corneal enlargement (buphthalmos), Haab’s striae, and optic disc cupping.


It does not cause leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) — which is the key finding in the image.

 

Hence, congenital glaucoma is not a differential diagnosis for leukocoria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Congenital cataract: Possible.


Congenital cataract causes leukocoria because the opaque lens blocks the red reflex.


Seen as a white reflex in the pupillary area, often detected in early infancy during screening.


It can be unilateral or bilateral, and prompt surgery is required to prevent amblyopia.

 

Option B. Persistent Hyperplastic Primary Vitreous (PHPV): Possible.


PHPV (also called Persistent Fetal Vasculature) is due to failure of regression of the fetal hyaloid vascular system.


It presents as unilateral leukocoria in an otherwise full-term infant with normal birth history.


Ultrasound or MRI shows a retrolental mass with a stalk from optic disc to lens.

 

Option C. Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP): Possible.
ROP occurs in premature infants (<32 weeks or <1500 g) who receive high oxygen therapy.


It leads to fibrovascular proliferation and retinal detachment, appearing as leukocoria in advanced stages.


Hence, it is a valid differential in premature infants

questions.text: Amblyopia management includes all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Strabismus surgery

 

Strabismus surgery is not a primary treatment for amblyopia itself — it corrects ocular alignment, but does not improve the amblyopic eye’s visual acuity.


If performed before proper visual stimulation therapy (like patching or penalization), the amblyopia may persist even after alignment.


Hence, amblyopia must be treated first (with patching and vision therapy), and strabismus surgery is done later for cosmetic and binocular alignment purposes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Patching: Correct Management.


Patching (occlusion therapy) involves covering the better eye to force use of the amblyopic (lazy) eye.


It stimulates visual cortex development and is the mainstay of amblyopia therapy.


Usually prescribed for 2–6 hours/day depending on severity and age.

 

Option B. Video games: Correct Management.


Special interactive video games and visual training programs help improve fixation and contrast sensitivity in the amblyopic eye.


These stimulate binocular cooperation and are used as an adjunct to traditional patching therapy.


They enhance compliance and neurovisual adaptation.

 

Option C. Refractive error correction: Correct Management.


Refractive correction using appropriate glasses or contact lenses is the first step in amblyopia management.


In anisometropic amblyopia, correcting the refractive difference alone can significantly improve vision.


Sometimes full correction for 4–6 weeks precedes patching therapy.

questions.text: A patient’s fundus photograph taken 48 hours after acute episode of pain abdomen is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Purtscher’s retinopathy

 

Purtscher’s retinopathy is a microvascular occlusive retinopathy associated with acute pancreatitis, chest compression injury, long bone fractures, or other severe systemic trauma.
It usually develops within 24–48 hours after the inciting event.

 

Typical Fundus Findings:

 

  • Purtscher flecken: polygonal, well-defined areas of retinal whitening between arterioles and venules.
  • Cotton wool spots: due to focal infarction of nerve fiber layer.
  • Retinal hemorrhages: usually few, around the posterior pole.
  • Macula may show edema → decreased vision.

 

Pathophysiology:


Complement activation → leukocyte aggregation → precapillary arteriolar occlusion → ischemia of the retina.

 

Hence, a patient developing these findings after acute pancreatitis or trauma is classic for Purtscher’s retinopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypertensive retinopathy: Incorrect.

 

  • Occurs in long-standing hypertension, not acutely after abdominal pain.
  • Shows arteriolar narrowing, A-V nicking, flame-shaped hemorrhages, and hard exudates forming a macular star.
  • No temporal relationship with pancreatitis or trauma.

 

Option B. Diabetic retinopathy: Incorrect.

 

  • A chronic microangiopathy seen in diabetics.
  • Fundus shows microaneurysms, dot and blot hemorrhages, hard exudates, and neovascularization.
  • Not associated with sudden systemic events like acute pancreatitis.

 

Option D. Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO): Incorrect.

 

  • Presents with sudden painless vision loss.
  • Fundus shows “blood and thunder” appearance: widespread hemorrhages, dilated tortuous veins, and cotton wool spots.
  • Unlike Purtscher’s, it is unilateral and not associated with trauma or pancreatitis

questions.text: A patient came to the ophthalmology OPD with corneal abrasion, corneal ulcer, corneal perforation and foreign body. Which of the following will not cause hypotonic maculopathy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Suprachoroidal hemorrhage

 

  • Suprachoroidal hemorrhage does not cause hypotonic maculopathy in this patient.
  • Signs of Suprachoroidal hemorrhage include the following:
  •  
    • Anterior chamber shallowing
    • Loss of the red reflex
    • Increased IOP, with firming of the eye
    • Wrinkling and bulging of the posterior capsule
    • Extrusion of intraocular contents: spontaneous nuclear expression, iris prolapse, vitreous prolapse
  • Maculopathy is a common consequence of hypotony, defined as IOP less than 5 mmHg.
  • Excessive drainage following glaucoma filtration surgery is the most common cause of hypotonic maculopathy.
  • Other causes include trauma (cyclodialysis cleft, penetrating injury), chronic uveitis, retinal detachment.
  • Systemic causes of hypotony, usually bilateral, include dehydration, uncontrolled diabetes with hyperglycaemia, uraemia, and treatment with hyperosmotic agents or carbonic anhydrase inhibitors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cyclodialysis of uvea: This refers to the disinsertion of the ciliary body from the scleral spur, a trauma-related occurrence that can lead to a direct decrease in IOP, potentially causing hypotonic maculopathy.

 

Option C. Corneal perforation: Severe enough corneal damage, such as perforation, can lead to loss of aqueous humor and a subsequent decrease in IOP, posing a risk for hypotonic maculopathy.

 

Option D. Filtration site leak: This condition is specifically associated with glaucoma surgery where a leak at the filtration site can lead to a significant reduction in IOP, making it a direct cause of hypotonic maculopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Suprachoroidal hemorrhage does not lead to hypotonic maculopathy because it typically causes an increase in intraocular pressure, not a decrease. Understanding the distinction between conditions that increase versus those that decrease IOP is critical in the management of eye conditions and their potential complications.

questions.text: A patient presented with painless decrease in vision and metamorphopsia. Fundus examination revealed the lesion shown in the image. What is the expected finding on ultrasonography?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Collar stud appearance  

 

The provided image depicts the right fundus of a patient, which indicates the presence of choroidal melanoma.

 

  • Angiography of the lesion: shows a distinct "double circulation" pattern, which represents the internal circulation within the tumor and the normal vascularity of the overlying retina.
  • On B-scan: pathognomonic feature called the "collar stud appearance" is visible. This appearance refers to a raised, dome-shaped tumor with a collar-like thickening at the base, caused by the accumulation of melanin and the infiltration of inflammatory cells at the tumor base.

 

 

Choroidal melanoma is a type of cancer that originates in the choroid, which is the vascular layer of the eye located between the retina and the sclera. It is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults and can lead to visual impairment and even metastasis to other organs. Therefore, it is crucial to diagnose and manage it promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Smoke-stack appearance: Typically associated with central serous retinopathy, showing a smoke-like leakage of fluid under the retina.

 

Option B. Inkblot appearance: Another pattern seen in central serous retinopathy where fluid leaks in a blot-like fashion.

 

Option D. Double circulation: While this feature can be seen in angiography of choroidal melanoma, it does not describe the ultrasonography appearance, which is specifically asked in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When diagnosing choroidal melanoma via ultrasonography, the "collar stud appearance" is a key finding. Recognizing this feature, along with the clinical presentation of painless visual loss and metamorphopsia, supports a timely and accurate diagnosis of this potentially life-threatening condition.
